docs.title: 📐 Polygon Area Calculator
docs.text:
Welcome to the official documentation for the Polygon Area Calculator — a clean, object-oriented Python module for working with rectangles and squares.

This project provides tools to compute:

  • Area
  • Perimeter
  • Diagonal length
  • ASCII-based shape drawings
  • How many times one shape can fit inside another
  • Class relationships (Square is a subclass of Rectangle)

All implemented using simple, well-structured Python classes.

docs.title: 🚀 Features
docs.text:
• 🟦 Rectangle Class with full geometric operations
  • 🟥 Square Class that inherits from Rectangle
  • 📐 Accurate shape-packing calculations
  • 🖼️ ASCII art drawing support
  • 🧪 Fully testable with pytest
  • 📘 Cleanly documented using MkDocs Material
  • 📦 Installable Python package (pip install .)

docs.title: 📚 Documentation Sections
docs.text:
Use the navigation on the left to explore:

  • Usage — How to use the Rectangle and Square classes
  • API Reference — Detailed method documentation
  • Examples — Practical demonstrations

docs.title: 🧩 Source Code
docs.text:
View the repository on GitHub:

👉 https://github.com/TheComputationalCore/Polygon-Area-Calculator

docs.title: 🧪 Running Tests
docs.text: ```bash pytest -q

docs.title: 📚 API Reference
docs.text: This page provides detailed documentation for all classes and methods in the Polygon Area Calculator project.

docs.title: 🟦 Rectangle
docs.text: The Rectangle class represents a simple rectangle defined by its width and height.

docs.title: Constructor
docs.text: Rectangle(width, height)

docs.title: Parameters:
docs.text:
• width (int or float)
  • height (int or float)

docs.title: 🔹 set_width(width)
docs.text:
Sets a new width.

rect.set_width(10)

docs.title: 🔹 set_height(height)
docs.text:
Sets a new height.

rect.set_height(5)

docs.title: 🔹 get_area()
docs.text:
Returns the area of the rectangle.

width * height

rect.get_area()

docs.title: 🔹 get_perimeter()
docs.text:
Returns the perimeter.

2 * width + 2 * height

rect.get_perimeter()

docs.title: 🔹 get_diagonal()
docs.text:
Returns the diagonal length based on the Pythorean theorem.

(width² + height²) ** 0.5

rect.get_diagonal()

docs.title: 🔹 get_picture()
docs.text:
Returns an ASCII-art representation of the rectangle using * characters.

  • If width or height is greater than 50, returns: Too big for picture.
print(rect.get_picture())

docs.title: 🔹 get_amount_inside(shape)
docs.text:
Returns how many times another shape can fit inside the rectangle.

Measured using integer division:

(self.width // shape.width) * (self.height // shape.height)

rect.get_amount_inside(sq)

docs.title: 🔹 __str__()
docs.text:
String representation of the rectangle:

Rectangle(width=10, height=5)

docs.title: 🟥 Square
docs.text: The Square class is a subclass of Rectangle, where both width and height remain equal.

docs.title: Constructor
docs.text: Square(side)

docs.title: Parameter:
docs.text: • side (int or float)

docs.title: 🔹 set_side(side)
docs.text:
Sets both width and height to the same value.

sq.set_side(6)

docs.title: 🔹 set_width(width) (overridden)
docs.text: Ensures width and height remain equal.

docs.title: 🔹 set_height(height) (overridden)
docs.text: Ensures width and height remain equal.

docs.title: 🔹 __str__()
docs.text:
String representation of a square:

Square(side=5)

docs.title: 🧱 Class Relationship Diagram
docs.text:
Rectangle
    ▲
    │ (inherits)
    │
 Square

docs.title: 🧩 Notes
docs.text:
• All geometric calculations return numeric values.
  • ASCII drawing uses * characters and line breaks.
  • Shape packing always uses integer division.

You may now continue to Examples or Usage for practical demonstrations.

docs.title: 🖥️ Command Line Interface (CLI)
docs.text: The Polygon Area Calculator includes a simple command-line interface for quickly computing properties of rectangles and squares without writing Python scripts.

docs.title: ▶️ Running the CLI
docs.text:
After installing the project (pip install .), run:

```bash polygon-calculator --help

docs.title: 📘 Examples
docs.text: This page contains complete examples demonstrating how to use the Polygon Area Calculator in real scenarios.

docs.title: 🧱 Example 1 — Basic Rectangle Usage
docs.text:
from polygon_calculator import Rectangle

rect = Rectangle(10, 5)

print(rect.get_area())        # 50
print(rect.get_perimeter())   # 30
print(rect.get_diagonal())    # 11.18...
print(rect.get_picture())

Output:

**********
**********
**********
**********
**********

docs.title: 🟥 Example 2 — Working With Squares
docs.text:
from polygon_calculator import Square

sq = Square(8)

print(sq.get_area())          # 64
sq.set_side(4)
print(sq.get_perimeter())     # 16
print(sq.get_picture())

Output:

****
****
****
****

docs.title: 🔄 Example 3 — Updating Dimensions
docs.text:
rect = Rectangle(12, 6)

rect.set_width(20)
rect.set_height(4)

print(rect)  
# Rectangle(width=20, height=4)

docs.title: 📦 Example 4 — Fitting Shapes Inside Each Other
docs.text:
rect = Rectangle(16, 8)
sq = Square(4)

print(rect.get_amount_inside(sq))   # 8

Explanation:

(16 // 4) * (8 // 4) = 4 * 2 = 8

docs.title: 🧩 Example 5 — Handling Too-Large Shapes for Pictures
docs.text:
rect = Rectangle(60, 4)
print(rect.get_picture())

Output:

Too big for picture.

docs.title: 📚 Continue Exploring
docs.text:
• Read the Usage Guide for step-by-step instructions
  • Check the API Reference for method descriptions

Happy coding! 🚀

docs.title: 📘 Usage Guide
docs.text: This guide explains how to use the Polygon Area Calculator to work with rectangles and squares using Python.

docs.title: Rectangle
docs.text:
from polygon_calculator import Rectangle

rect = Rectangle(10, 5)

docs.title: Square
docs.text:
from polygon_calculator import Square

sq = Square(9)

Both classes store width and height internally. Square ensures both values always remain equal.

docs.title: Rectangle
docs.text:
rect.set_width(12)
rect.set_height(4)

docs.title: Square
docs.text:
sq.set_side(6)
# or
sq.set_width(6)
sq.set_height(6)

docs.title: Area
docs.text:
rect.get_area()      # width * height
sq.get_area()

docs.title: Perimeter
docs.text:
rect.get_perimeter()
sq.get_perimeter()

docs.title: Diagonal
docs.text:
rect.get_diagonal()
sq.get_diagonal()

docs.title: 🖼️ Generating Shape Pictures
docs.text:
You can generate ASCII-based visual representations:

print(rect.get_picture())

Example output:

**********
**********
**********

Shapes larger than 50 in width or height return:

Too big for picture.

docs.title: 📦 Packing Shapes Inside Each Other
docs.text:
Determine how many times one shape fits inside another:

rect = Rectangle(16, 8)
sq = Square(4)

rect.get_amount_inside(sq)   # returns 8

This calculates:

(rect.width // sq.width) * (rect.height // sq.height)

docs.title: 📄 String Representations
docs.text:
Each class has a descriptive __str__:

print(Rectangle(3, 6))
# Rectangle(width=3, height=6)

print(Square(5))
# Square(side=5)

docs.text:
